name: student-essays
description: Grade student essays and written assignments by quality

categories.name: Developing
categories.description: Shows promise, needs specific feedback on key areas

categories.name: Needs Work
categories.description: Significant gaps in argument, evidence, or structure

top_priorities: Clear thesis or central argument supported by evidence
Logical structure and coherent progression of ideas
Genuine engagement with source material (not just summary)
Original thinking beyond restating what others have said

highly_valued: Original analysis that goes beyond summarizing sources
Specific, concrete examples rather than vague generalities
bonus_points: Surprising or creative connections between ideas
Sophisticated use of evidence from multiple sources
Writing that is genuinely engaging to read

deal_breakers: Off-topic -- does not address the assignment prompt
negative_factors: Unsupported claims or opinions stated as fact
Disorganized structure that's hard to follow
Frequent grammar or spelling errors that impede comprehension

specific_guidance: A shorter essay with a clear, well-supported argument beats a longer one that rambles.
Don't penalize unconventional structure if the ideas flow logically.
Distinguish between surface errors (typos, formatting) and substantive issues (weak argument, missing evidence).
A Developing essay shows understanding but hasn't pushed into analysis. A Needs Work essay has fundamental gaps.
philosophy: Reward critical thinking and clear communication over polish. A rough essay with genuine insight outranks a polished essay that says nothing new.
